Lesson 1: identify the media messages used in this crash course video.
Hint: everything is for views.

Media Messages don't exist due to the death of the author. the only meaning that exists in media is the meaning that the consumer is able to take out of it, Even if that meaning was not deliberately placed in it, and there is no way to control for what meaning a consumer can take out of any media, Therefor, Media itself has no morality, and you are not responsible for the "effect" any media you create can have, because it is impossible to accurately predict, unless the media contains a very clear and explicitly stated message which is actually spoken out word for word such as a character making a persuasive argument, at which point the argument itself has a message, not the media that the argument is contained in, which is especially important when the argument itself is also contradicted within the media, or the argument is not shown in a positive light.

I earned my MA in Media Literacy, and I'm really happy to see this on here. For those engaging in Media Literacy for the first time, it's important to remember that literacy involves both reading AND writing (or, in ML's case, interpretation and production). Analyzing how media is created is aided by creating media itself. Once you learn some of the theory behind media, apply it to your own work, and you'll learn a lot more about the media creation process!
I'm into it

How do we build the 'dictionaries' that Jay is talking about when decoding messages? I suppose the obvious answer is from cultural experience, but this seems a little too broad. Can anyone give a concise explanation of how it is we come to be able to interpret all of the messages displayed and broadcasted to us, almost effortlessly, in our day-to-day lives?

How are teens consuming less media?  Most days in my teens I was required to consume 6 hours of media a day in school lessons, and the days I had PE or DT instead it only replaced one of those hours. Of course that's interactive media as you can ask questions and correct your teacher, and it's fairly questionable how much one can influence the message of mathematics, but it's still media and especially when it comes to the humanities and sciences are incredibly influential forms of it. And then they come home and do and hour or more of homework from a text book (more media) and spend even more hours watching TV, youtube, reading twitter or playing video-games.
